main event: A bright light, approximately ten times the apparent size of a star, was observed in the sky west of Misawa Air Base, Japan on February 23, 1961.
interesting points: The light was intermittently visible and its intensity varied considerably.
The movement of the object appeared to be a slow drifting and a slow rotating white luminous object.
The color of the light ranged from pinkish white to reddish white.
Several individuals observed the phenomenon and stated that it was much larger than a star and suddenly vanished.
The movement of the light appeared to be northward at a slow speed.
result: The case was concluded as an observation of the planet Venus. The intermittent visibility, apparent change in size, and coloring of the object were attributed to atmospheric distortion and the motion of Venus relative to the observers.
sighted object: A bright light, approximately ten times the apparent size of a star
photographs: No photographs were included in the report.
